questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the patient having the following type of karyotype, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Down Syndrome

Explanation:

  • The karyotype is showing three copies of chromosome 21, which indicates it is a case of Down syndrome. Down Syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, resulting in a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the normal 46.

 

Key features of Karyotyping:

  • A karyotype is a visual representation of an individual's chromosomes, arranged in pairs by size and position of the centromere.
  • In a normal human karyotype, 46 chromosomes are arranged in 23 pairs (22 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes).
  • The chromosomes are photographed during metaphase, when they are most condensed and visible.
  • They are then arranged in descending order of size, with the sex chromosomes placed last.
     

Turner Syndrome (Option A) is characterized by monosomy X, which means there is an absence or partial deletion of one of the X chromosomes, resulting in a karyotype of 45, XO. The presented karyotype shows three copies of chromosome 21, not a missing X chromosome. Turner syndrome affects only females and is associated with short stature and ovarian dysfunction.

Klinefelter Syndrome (Option C) presents with an extra X chromosome in males, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. The karyotype image clearly shows trisomy 21, not an extra X chromosome. Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by tall stature, infertility, and delayed puberty.

Edward Syndrome (Option D) also known as Trisomy 18, is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 18, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XX+18 or 47, XY+18. The provided karyotype shows an extra chromosome 21, not chromosome 18. Edward syndrome is associated with severe developmental delays and multiple congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A teenage boy, who was previously raised as a girl, presents with primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. On examination, he has tall stature, small testes, and gynecomastia. Testosterone level was normal. Which of the following is the most likely genotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 47,XXY:

Explanation: The presentation fits Klinefelter syndrome, a condition with 47,XXY karyotype.

Key features include:

  • Genotypic male but with small, firm testes and primary testicular failure
  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs
  • Gynecomastia and sparse facial/body hair
  • Often detected at puberty due to delayed secondary sexual characteristics or infertility
  • Testosterone may be in the low–normal range due to Leydig cell dysfunction, with elevated gonadotropins (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)

Incorrect Options:

45,X (Option A): Turner syndrome - short stature, streak gonads, female phenotype.

46,XX (Option B): Normal female karyotype, not consistent with male phenotype.

47,XYY (Option D): Tall males with normal fertility; usually asymptomatic or may have learning difficulties.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic for developmental assessment. On examination, he has a prominent epicanthal fold, a single transverse palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability. Facial features appear flat with upslanting palpebral fissures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Down syndrome

Explanation: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21 and is the most common chromosomal cause of intellectual disability.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.

  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.

The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis:

General Features:

  • Intellectual disability

  • Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).

  • Small nose with flat nasal bridge

  • Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue

  • Significant hypotonia

  • Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears

  • Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)

  • Simian crease on the palm

  • A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap)

Comorbidities

  • Congenital Heart Disease:: 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF. Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.

  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.

  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.

  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.

  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.

  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.

  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.

  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.

  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Patau syndrome (Option B): Caused by trisomy 13; associated with cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microphthalmia, and holoprosencephaly, not the described features.

Edward syndrome (Option C): Caused by trisomy 18; features include clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, micrognathia, and severe growth restriction.

Fragile X syndrome (Option D): X-linked condition with intellectual disability, macroorchidism, long narrow face, and large ears. But, lacks the facial features and palmar crease of Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which genetic syndrome is caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cri-du-chat syndrome:

Explanation: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion). The name “cri-du-chat” (French for “cry of the cat”) refers to the characteristic high-pitched, cat-like cry of affected infants due to laryngeal hypoplasia and abnormal development of the nervous system.

  • Other features include microcephaly, hypertelorism, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, developmental delay, and severe intellectual disability.

Incorrect Options:

Edward syndrome (Option A): Caused by trisomy 18, not 5p deletion.

Patau syndrome (Option B): Caused by trisomy 13, not 5p deletion.

Turner syndrome (Option D): Caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome (45,XO), not 5p deletion.

questions.text: Which is correct about estriol level in Down’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Low:

  • Estriol levels are often lower in pregnancies with Down syndrome. This is one of the markers measured in maternal serum screening for Down syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No change: Estriol levels are typically affected in pregnancies with Down syndrome, so there is usually a change in estriol levels.

Option C - Elevated: Estriol levels are not typically elevated in pregnancies with Down syndrome.

Option D - Double-triple: Estriol levels are not expected to be double or triple in pregnancies with Down syndrome. Instead, they are more likely to be reduced.

In summary, the correct relationship about estriol levels in Down's syndrome is that they are often Low.

questions.text: A child with fused carpal bones comes to your clinic. What is the gene associated with hand-feet syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HOXA13

Explanation:

Hand-Foot-Genital Syndrome (HFGS):

  • Rare, dominantly inherited condition affecting distal limbs and genitourinary tract.
  • Genetic cause:
    • Identified mutation in the HOXA13 homeobox gene.
    • HFGS is the second human syndrome linked to a HOX gene mutation.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Limb Malformations:
      • Bilateral shortening of thumbs and great toes, typically involving distal phalanx or first metacarpal/metatarsal.
      • Impaired dexterity or thumb apposition due to the malformations.
    • Urogenital Defects:
      • In females: Abnormalities in the ureters and urethra, incomplete müllerian fusion.
      • In males: Hypospadias with or without chordee.
      • Associated conditions: Vesicoureteral reflux, recurrent urinary tract infections, and chronic pyelonephritis.
      • Normal fertility.
  • Diagnosis and Testing:
    • Clinical Diagnosis:
      • Physical examination, radiographs of hands/feet, and imaging of kidneys, bladder, and female reproductive tract.
    • Genetic Diagnosis:
      • Identification of a heterozygous HOXA13 pathogenic variant confirms diagnosis if clinical/radiographic features are unclear.
  • Management:
    • Treatment of Manifestations:
      • Surgery for hand/foot malformations is usually unnecessary.
      • Ureteric reimplantation and bladder outlet abnormality correction often needed.
      • Rare surgical correction for vaginal septum or uterine abnormalities, unless recurrent pregnancy loss occurs.
    • Prevention of Secondary Complications:
      • Prophylactic antibiotics or surgery for urinary tract issues.
      • Gynecological exams before menstruation for hymenal constriction.
      • Pre-pregnancy evaluation for uterine and vaginal anatomy due to risks in pregnancy.

BCL6 gene (Option B) mutations are associated with B cell lymphomas and other cancers.

FGFR gene (Option C) mutation causes skeletal disorders, mainly dwarfism and craniofacial malformations.

COI 11 (Option D) mutation is associated with hearing loss.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 10-year-old boy who was brought for psychiatric evaluation due to intellectual disability and exhibits an IQ of 45? The boy also presents with physical characteristics such as a long face, large ears, and large testes, along with a cardiac murmur. Additionally, there is a history of poor intellectual function in the paternal family.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Fragile X syndrome

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with the classic triad of physical features, including a long face, large ears, and macroorchidism (large testes), along with intellectual disability (IQ 45) and a cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral valve prolapse, which indicates Fragile X syndrome.
  • The X-linked inheritance pattern is supported by the paternal family history of poor intellectual function.
  • This condition is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, making it the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability.

Fragile X Syndrome:

Genetic Basis

CGG repeats on FMR-1 (Familial mental retardation) gene on X chromosome

CGG Repeat Numbers
  • Normal population: 5-55 repeats
  • Carriers (premutation): 55-200 repeats
  • Fragile X Syndrome: >200 repeats

Gender Prevalence
  • More common in males (X-Linked Dominant Inheritance)
  • Females mostly carriers

Clinical Features
  • Long face & large ears
  • Large mandible/Prominent jaw
  • High arched palate
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Macroorchidism/large testes (seen in adolescent age group)
  • Intellectual disability

Clinical features of female carriers

  • May be associated with premature ovarian failure
  • 10% may have an intellectual disability/low IQ

Incorrect options:

Cushing's syndrome (Option A): While this condition can affect growth and development, it typically presents with central obesity, moon face, and buffalo hump. The characteristic features of large ears and macroorchidism are not associated with Cushing's syndrome.

Rett syndrome (Option B): This condition primarily affects females and is characterized by progressive loss of motor functions such as inability to speak, use hands, walk or perform other activities. It does not present with distinctive facial features or macroorchidism.

William syndrome (Option D): While this condition can cause intellectual disability and cardiac abnormalities, it typically presents with elfin facies and a distinctive "cocktail party" personality.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Liver iron concentration

 

Explanation: Liver iron concentration is the best method to detect iron overload in thalassemia patients undergoing multiple blood transfusions.

 

Iron Overload in Thalassemia:

  • Iron Overload Mechanisms in Thalassemia:
    • TDT (Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia):
      • Regular blood transfusions lead to iron accumulation (0.3-0.6 mg/kg per day).
      • Iron is released into plasma after transfused red blood cells are phagocytized and binds to transferrin.
      • Once transferrin is saturated, non-transferrin-bound iron enters organs like the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
      • Iron accumulation causes organ damage via reactive oxygen species.
    • NTDT (Non-Transfusion-Dependent Thalassemia):
      • Increased intestinal iron absorption due to hepcidin suppression and ineffective erythropoiesis.
      • Iron primarily accumulates in the liver, not the myocardium, unlike in TDT.
         
  • Diagnosis and Quantification of Iron Overload:
    • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
  • MRI with R2 or T2 technique is the gold standard for quantifying liver iron concentration (LIC) and cardiac iron in thalassemia.
  • Iron Overload Thresholds:
    • LIC in NTDT: Values >5 mg/g correlate with increased morbidity.
    • LIC in TDT:
      • 7 mg/g dw indicates increased risk of complications.
      • 15 mg/g dw is predictive of advanced liver fibrosis and increased cardiac risk.
  • Cardiac T2 MRI: (Option B)
    • <10 ms predicts higher risk of heart failure and mortality.
    • 10-20 ms is linked to reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and arrhythmias.
    • However there can be discrepancy between liver iron and cardiac iron levels.
  • Serum Ferritin Assessment: (Option C)
    • Used as a screening tool.
    • Ferritin levels correlate with hepatic iron overload in both TDT and NTDT.
    • However, it is not as accurate for detecting iron overload in thalassemia patients, as ferritin levels can be elevated due to other factors (e.g., inflammation).
  • Non-Transferrin-Bound Iron (NTBI): (Option D)
    • Refers to iron that is not bound to transferrin, typically occurring in iron overload conditions when iron exceeds the binding capacity of transferrin.
    • NTBI is a labile form of iron that can contribute to iron toxicity.
    • While NTBI can serve as an indicator of iron overload, it is influenced by plasma factors like citrate, uric acid, and albumin.
       
  • Management of Iron Overload in Thalassemia:
    • Iron Chelation Therapy (ICT):
  • Aims to manage iron stores, reduce iron in tissues, and reverse heart failure.
  • Three main chelators used: Deferoxamine (DFO), Deferiprone (DFP), and Deferasirox (DFX).
  • TDT: Start ICT after 10 transfusions or by age 2 years.
  • NTDT: Begin assessment at age 10, with consideration for MRI-based evaluation of organ-specific iron load from age 8-10 years.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient?


	High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
	PT and APTT
	Bone marrow
	Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
The clinical features of progressive pallor and abdominal distension, along with a Mentzer index less than 13, point towards a diagnosis of thalassemia, and the investigations to be done include High-performance liquid chromatography and a peripheral blood smear.

 

Mentzer Index Calculation:

  • MCV (in fL) / RBC count (in millions per microliter).
  • Index Value:
    • > 13: Suggests iron deficiency anemia (IDA).
    • < 13: Indicates a higher likelihood of beta-thalassemia.

 

Beta thalassemia:

  • Results from mutations in the HBB gene on chromosome 11, which encodes the beta globin chains.
  • Humans have two beta globin genes, and mutations in one or both genes lead to different severities of beta-thalassemia.

Beta Thalassemias

Major (Transfusion-dependent)

Intermedia (Non-transfusion-dependent)

Minor (Trait or Carrier)

Genotype

Homozygous:

β⁰/β⁰

β⁰/β⁺

β⁺/β⁺

Variable:

β⁰/β⁺ or β⁺/β⁺ or β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Heterozygous:

β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Peripheral Smear


 

Severe microcytic anemia with target cells (Hb 3–4 g/dL)

Moderate microcytic anemia

Mild microcytic anemia

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

HbA₂ (5% or more);

HbF (up to 95%); No HbA

HbA₂ (4% or more);

HbF (up to 50%)

HbA₂ (4% or more);

HbF (up to 5%)
  • β⁰: No beta-globin production
  • β⁺: Decreased beta-globin production

 

Feature

Beta Thalassemia Minor (Trait)

Beta Thalassemia Intermedia

Beta Thalassemia Major (Cooley's Anemia)

Genetic Mutation

One beta-globin gene mutated, and the other is functional

Both beta-globin genes mutated but allowed some beta-chain production

Both beta-globin genes are severely mutated or absent

Severity of Anemia

Mild, often asymptomatic

Moderate anaemia

Severe anaemia, evident early in life (usually within the first year)

Symptoms

Typically asymptomatic, with mild fatigue

Pallor, jaundice, delayed growth, bone deformities

Profound fatigue, failure to thrive, bone deformities, hepatosplenomegaly

Age of Onset

Usually diagnosed incidentally through routine blood tests

Variable; symptoms often arise in childhood

Symptoms present within the first year of life

Blood Transfusions

Rarely needed

Occasional transfusions, particularly during stress/illness

Regular, lifelong transfusions required

Iron Overload

Rare

May occur if frequent transfusions are given

Significant risk due to frequent transfusions; iron chelation therapy needed

Complications

None significant

Splenomegaly, growth delay, bone changes

Iron overload complications (heart, liver damage), severe growth issues

Hemoglobin Levels

Slightly reduced

Moderately reduced

Severely reduced (Hemoglobin levels often <7 g/dL without transfusions)

Hb Electrophoresis

Normal or slight increase in HbA2

Increased HbA2 and possibly HbF

Elevated HbF with very low or absent HbA

HPLC

Normal hemoglobin profile

Abnormal profile with increased HbA2 and/or HbF

Abnormal profile with high levels of HbF and very low HbA

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern observed in neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Neural tube defects (NTDs) are a group of congenital malformations that affect brain and spinal cord development. Examples of NTDs include spina bifida, anencephaly, and encephalocele.

The pattern of Inheritance in NTDs is complex and can involve multiple genetic and environmental factors. While no single gene has been identified as causing NTDs, there is evidence to suggest that multiple genes may be involved.
In addition to genetic factors, environmental factors such as maternal folic acid deficiency, certain medications, and exposure to toxins can also increase the risk of NTDs.

Therefore, the inheritance pattern in NTDs is considered to be multifactorial, meaning that genetic and environmental factors contribute to the development of the condition.

 

Incorrect Choices:

a. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when a single copy of a mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs

b. X-linked dominant: X-linked dominant inheritance occurs when a mutated gene on the X chromosome is responsible for the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs

c. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance occurs when an individual inherits two copies of a mutated gene, one from each parent. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caudal regression

Explanation:

  • Among the provided options, caudal regression is not associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression is a condition characterized by the abnormal development of the lower spine and limbs, and it is more frequently seen in infants of diabetic mothers rather than those with Down syndrome.

Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

 

Cause
  • Trisomy 21 due to meiotic nondisjunction.
  • Less commonly caused by Robertsonian translocation (4%) or mosaicism (1%).

Incidence

1:800 to 1:1000 live births.

General Features

Craniofacial:

  • Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes, epicanthic folds.
  • Small nose, flat nasal bridge, narrow palate, small teeth, protruding tongue.
  • Brachycephaly, flat occiput, dysplastic ears.

 

Extremities:

  • Short, broad hands, clinodactyly (5th finger), simian crease, sandal gap (wide space between toes).

Comorbidities

Cardiac: 40-60% have congenital heart defects (mainly AVSD, VSD, PDA, ASD).

Gastrointestinal: Duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung disease, annular pancreas.

Hematological: Increased risk of leukemia (acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia).

Endocrine: Thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism), type 1 diabetes risk.

Neurological: Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (APP gene on chromosome 21).

Musculoskeletal: Atlanto-occipital subluxation, short stature, hypotonia, growth delays, obesity risk.

Sensory: Hearing loss (conductive, often due to serous otitis media), ophthalmic problems (cataracts, strabismus, nystagmus).

Diagnosis

Prenatal:

  • Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS): Performed between 10-13 weeks.
  • Amniocentesis: Performed after 15 weeks.

Postnatal:

  • Characteristic features (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphisms).
  • Confirmatory Test: Karyotype analysis for trisomy 21.

Antenatal Screening

First Trimester: Increased nuchal translucency (>3 mm), elevated β-HCG, low PAPP-A.

Second Trimester: Triple Test (β-HCG, estriol, AFP), Quadruple Test (adds Inhibin-A).

Integrated Test: Combines maternal age, NT, PAPP-A, and Quadruple Test.

Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPS/NIPT): Cell-free fetal DNA testing (high sensitivity and specificity).

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trofinetide

Explanation:

  • Trofinetide is the newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Rett syndrome, a rare neurodevelopmental disorder primarily affecting females.
  • Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of the amino-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1), designed to reduce neuroinflammation and support synaptic function.
  • It is believed to work by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production, reducing overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and enhancing IGF-1 signaling in the brain, which is crucial for normal development and response to injury.

 

Rett Syndrome

  • Neurological disorder mostly affecting girls.
  • Caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene.
  • Characterized by normal early development, followed by loss of motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements.

 

Development and Symptoms

  • Early Development: Normal for the first 6-18 months.
  • Loss of Skills: After early development, motor skills, speech, and purposeful hand movements are lost.
  • Repetitive Hand Movements: Common signs include hand-wringing, clapping, or tapping.
  • Motor Dysfunction: Loss of coordination, walking problems, and abnormal gait.
  • Cognitive Impairment: Intellectual disability and delayed language development.
  • Seizures: Commonly occur in many cases.

Diagnosis: Genetic Testing to detect mutations in the MECP2 gene.

Management:

Symptom Management

  • Antiepileptic drugs (e.g., valproic acid, lamotrigine) for seizures.
  • SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Torfenetide: An investigational drug targeting MECP2 gene abnormalities to potentially enhance neurological function.
  • Motor Support
  • Speech Therapy
  • Behavioral Therapy

Olcegepant (Option A): A calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist that was considered for migraine treatment but was discontinued.

Lasmiditan (Option B): A 5HT1F receptor-selective agonist used for treating migraine.

Erenumab (Option D): A CGRP-blocking antibody used for treating migraines.

questions.text: Which chromosomal defect is suggested by the karyotyping results given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trisomy 18

Explanation:

The karyotype analysis reveals Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) based on the following findings:

  • Total chromosome count: 47
  • Sex chromosomes: XY (male)
  • Extra chromosome: +18 (three copies of chromosome 18)

The presence of three copies of chromosome 18 confirms Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Trisomy 13 (Option B): Incorrect, as Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) would show 47, XY, +13, not +18.

Trisomy 21 (Option C): Incorrect, as Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is characterized by 47, XY, +21, not +18.

Trisomy 11 (Option D): Not a recognized viable trisomy in humans.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with Turner syndrome. Which of the following are features of Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Webbed neck

Explanation:

  • The image shows a webbed neck, which is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome (45, XO) is a chromosomal disorder characterized by the absence of one X chromosome in females.

 

Turner syndrome has multiple clinical manifestations that can be categorized using the SABLCOWN mnemonic:

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome (Mnemonic- SABCLOWN)

S
  • Short stature
  • Short 4th metacarpal
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

A
  • Amenorrhea (Primary)

B
  • Barr body absent

C
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Cubitus valgus

L
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Lymphedema of hands and feet
  • Low thyroid (Hypothyroidism)

O
  • Ovaries streak-shaped/underdeveloped
  • Rudimentary uterus

W
  • Webbed neck

N
  • Nipples are widely spaced on a shield-shaped chest
  • Normal intelligence

 

Normal height (Option B): Short stature is a cardinal feature of Turner syndrome. Growth failure typically becomes evident by age 3-5 years, and final adult height is significantly reduced without growth hormone therapy.

Decreased carrying angle (Option C): Turner syndrome is characterized by an increased carrying angle (cubitus valgus), not a decreased angle. This increased carrying angle is one of the characteristic skeletal manifestations of the condition.

Gynecomastia (Option D): Gynecomastia is not a feature of Turner syndrome. Gynecomastia is associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY). Turner syndrome typically presents with widely spaced nipples on a shield-shaped chest.

questions.text: At what age is surgery typically performed for cleft lip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3 months

 

Explanation:

 

Surgery for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age following the "Rule of 10s", which provides safe criteria for timing of the operation:

  • 10 weeks of age

  • 10 pounds (approx. 4.5 kg) body weight

  • 10 g/dL haemoglobin

This early repair helps with feeding, speech development, and aesthetic outcomes.

 

6 months (Option B): Is later than the usual timing for cleft lip repair. By this time, cleft palate repair may be planned.

1 year (Option C): Typical age for cleft palate surgery, not lip.

18 months (Option D): Too late for primary cleft lip repair; may be considered for revision surgeries or speech surgeries if required.

questions.text: What is the most likely karyotype for a 16-year-old girl who presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and widely spaced nipples?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - 45, XO

  • The patient’s presentation with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and widely spaced nipples is suggestive of Turner syndrome.
  • The karyotype of this patient is 45, XO.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: In which trimester is a quadruple test done for antenatal screening of Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2nd trimester:

  • The quadruple screening test is offered to pregnant women in the second trimester (from 14 to 20 weeks gestation).
  • Four biochemical markers are analysed and combined with maternal age to generate a quadruple screening test result.
  • These comprise:
    • α-fetoprotein (AFP)
    • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or free β-hCG
    • Inhibin A
    • Unconjugated oestriol

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Female pseudohermaphroditism:

  • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, female pseudohermaphroditism occurs when there is prenatal exposure to excess androgens due to the enzyme deficiency.
  • It leads to virilization of the external female genitalia, causing them to appear more masculine.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ataxia telangiectasia is false?

choices.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance:

  • Ataxia telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Mutations in 11q gene is implicated: Ataxia telangiectasia is caused by mutations in the ATM gene located on chromosome 11q.

Option C: Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency: Ataxia telangiectasia is associated with both humoral (antibody-mediated) and cellular (T-cell-mediated) immunodeficiency.

Option D: Linked to adenocarcinomas: Individuals with ataxia telangiectasia have an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, including lymphomas, leukemia, and certain solid tumors such as breast and gastric adenocarcinomas.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions is characteristic of an X-linked disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Color blindness:

  • Color blindness is a X-linked disorder.
  • It is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of photopigments in the cone cells of the retina.
  • These mutations lead to a deficiency or absence of the photopigments, resulting in an inability to distinguish certain colors, particularly shades of red and green.

Incorrect Options - Options B, C, and D are autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.text: What are the accurate characteristics of ovotesticular disorders of sex development?

choices.text: Ovotesticular disorder of sex development can be identified in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ovotesticular disorder of sex development can be identified in the gonadal biopsy:

  • Ovotestis, which contains both ovarian and testicular tissue, can be identified in the gonadal biopsy of individuals with ovotesticular disorders of sex development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: The karyotype is 46 XY: Ovotesticular disorders of sex development can have various karyotypes, including 46 XX, 46 XY, or mosaic patterns.

Option C: The response of testosterone to hCG is increased: The response of testosterone to human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) stimulation is typically decreased in individuals with ovotesticular disorders of sex development.

Option D: Uterus is usually absent: While the presence or absence of a uterus can vary in ovotesticular disorders of sex development, it is possible for individuals with this condition to have a uterus.

questions.text: Which chromosome is affected in Hunter disease, leading to an abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - X chromosome:

  • Hunter syndrome, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II, is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate sulfatase.
  • The defective gene responsible for the condition is located on the X chromosome.

Incorrect Options -B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What type of genetic inheritance is indicated by the pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Autosomal-recessive disorder:

  • In an autosomal-recessive disorder, the affected individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene, one from each parent, in order to express the disorder.
  • Carriers (heterozygous individuals) do not show symptoms but can pass on the mutated gene to their offspring.
  • The disorder can skip generations and is typically seen in individuals who have two affected parents or when both parents are carriers.
  • Examples of autosomal-recessive disorders include cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Autosomal-dominant disorder:

  • In an autosomal-dominant disorder, the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring.
  • The disorder typically appears in every generation, and both males and females can be affected.
  • Unaffected individuals do not transmit the disorder to their offspring.
  • Examples of autosomal-dominant disorders include Huntington's disease and Marfan syndrome.

Option B: X-linked dominant disorder:

  • In an X-linked dominant disorder, an affected male passes the mutated gene to all of his daughters but none of his sons.
  • Affected females have a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring, regardless of gender.
  • The disorder can appear in every generation, but it is more commonly observed in females.
  • Examples of X-linked dominant disorders include Rett syndrome and Incontinentia Pigmenti.

Option D: X-linked recessive disorder:

  • In an X-linked recessive disorder, affected males pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters but none of their sons.
  • Carrier females have a 50% chance of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring.
  • The disorder is more commonly observed in males.
  • Examples of X-linked recessive disorders include hemophilia and Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
